article.description: Seimone Augustus scored 19 points and the Lady Tigers fought off a second-half charge by Southwest Missouri State with a late 16-0 run in a 66-54 victory in the Triple Crown Classic on Saturday.
article.headline: Lady Tigers use 16-0 run to put game away
article.linkText: Perfect 10: LSU holds on to stay perfect
article.story:
SPRINGFIELD, Mo. (AP) -- For the second time in four days, top-ranked LSU passed a difficult road test.

Seimone Augustus scored 19 points and the Lady Tigers fought off a second-half charge by Southwest Missouri State with a late 16-0 run in a 66-54 victory in the Triple Crown Classic on Saturday.

"It was the perfect game for us," LSU coach Pokey Chatman said. "What an environment to play in. You can't mimic this."

LSU (10-0) followed up a 75-67 victory at No. 13 Minnesota on Tuesday by shooting 54 percent and holding Southwest Missouri to 36.5 percent. The biggest obstacle was a raucous near-sellout crowd of 8,431 in the bandbox Hammons Center.

"I couldn't hear myself," Chatman said. "It made you focus to be a really good communicating team."

LSU ended Southwest Missouri's 24-game home-court winning streak, the fourth-longest in the nation, despite often sluggish play and 19 turnovers. Sylvia Fowles had 11 points and 10 rebounds and Scholanda Hoston had 13 points for the Lady Tigers, who trailed 49-47 with 6:26 left before pulling away.

"It wasn't our best game," said Augustus, who was 9-for-12. "We were stagnant on offense, but as the game went on we progressed."

Jenni Lingor had 16 points and nine rebounds and reserve Kari Koch added 14 points for Southwest Missouri (4-4). The Lady Bears shot 48 percent in the second half after a 26 percent showing in the first half to give the unanimous top-ranked team a scare.

"If we were going to lose to anybody, it might as well be to the No. 1 team in the country," Southwest Missouri coach Katie Abrahamson-Henderson said. "You can tell why they're the No. 1 team."

LSU freshmen contributed nine points in the decisive run that put the Lady Tigers comfortably ahead 63-49 with two minutes left. Quianna Chaney had five of her 10 points on a 3-pointer and pull-up jumper and Fowles had four points.

Ashley Thomas' only points of the game on a layup and three-point play off a missed free throw made it 57-49.

"They took advantage of our little mistakes," Lingor said. "They got wide-open layups and got in the passing lanes. It was more of a mental lapse than a physical one."

Southwest Missouri outscored LSU 21-9 over an eight-minute stretch midway through the second half, erasing a 12-point deficit and tying it at 45 when Koch scored off a loose ball with 8:11 left. Koch and Lingor each had seven points in that run, and Sarah Klaassen's layup gave the Lady Bears their only lead.

"It seemed like our lead just evaporated," Chatman said. "We had to adjust to their defense, to the way the game was called and to the crowd."

LSU capitalized on a smothering defense that held Southwest Missouri to a 2-for-10 shooting start, grabbing a 16-4 lead with 9:40 to go in the first half. Foul problems kept the Lady Tigers from extending that advantage, with both Wendlyn Jones and Temeke Johnson sidelined much of the half.

Lingor, who averages 23.6 points on 55 percent shooting, was 5-for-18 overall and 1-for-7 from 3-point range. She had six turnovers that offset four assists. Lingor had scored 20 or more points in each of the last six games.

LSU's win marked the 600th for the program in its 30th season.
